author: Natalie O'Neill
title: Woman gives barista apology card, cash after her ‘rudeness’ | New York Post
text:
Californians don’t know beans about rudeness!
A touchy-feely Golden State woman felt so bad about getting mildly snippy with a Starbucks barista, she gave him an apology card and $50 cash.
Andrew Richardson, 20, was working the drive-through window at the coffee shop in Bishop, California, on March 20 when the “less-than-cheerful” lady pulled up, according a press release from the company .
She ordered drinks, requested a carrier and asked him if he would throw away some trash from her car.
Her passive-aggressive attitude started brewing when he told her “no,” citing California health code. She grew annoyed and started being “curt,” according to Starbucks.
“She was mildly irritated, but she was still pleasant with me,” Richardson said.
If there was a rudeness scale, “It was like a 2 on a scale of 10 for me,” he added.
But the woman felt so guilty, she came back the next day and handed him a card.
“I need to apologize,” she wrote. “Yesterday at your drive thru we had a less than cheerful encounter. At no fault of yours, you said you could not take my empty cup (trash). I was less than understanding. My manner was curt,” read the card, which was signed “Debbie.”
She added, “The thought of leaving a trail of unkindness like that is so not the path I want to reflect.”
She encouraged him to “Keep up your attitude of cheer and hope” and added, “You taught this ole Lady something yesterday.”
The barista was stunned because he’d barely thought twice about the interaction.
“She was so nice and so kind. I just really wasn’t expecting that. It was very, very heartwarming,” Richardson said.
